perturbation.original_text:
Producer shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless ConvergTV and its parents, subsidiaries, divisions, officers, directors, employees, attorneys and agents, and their respective successors or assigns, from all costs, expenses and damages arising from any breach or alleged breach of the warranties made by it in this Agreement.

Producer shall further indemnify, defend and hold harmless ConvergTV and its parents, subsidiaries, divisions, officers, directors, employees, attorneys and agents, and their respective successors or assigns, from all costs, expenses and damages arising from any costs, errors, omissions, slander, losses, liability or for any other cause as a direct or indirect result of the Distribution, transmission or publication of the Producer’s Program or content.
perturbation.changed_text:
Producer shall indemnify ConvergTV from damages directly resulting from a material breach of this Agreement, not to exceed the revenue received by the Producer from ConvergTV under this Agreement.

Producer shall further indemnify ConvergTV from damages directly resulting from gross negligence in the Distribution of the Producer's Program, capped at $1000.00 USD.
perturbation.explanation: The original indemnification clause is broad, encompassing all costs, expenses, and damages arising from any breach or alleged breach. The modified clause severely limits the Producer's liability by capping the indemnification amount and requiring a direct causal link and gross negligence. This contradicts Florida law regarding indemnification clauses, which require clear and unambiguous language and proportionality. The cap could be deemed unconscionable if it doesn't adequately cover potential losses. This removal of implied consumer protections creates legal risk for ConvergTV, as they may not be fully protected from liability.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida Statutes regarding contract law, indemnification, and unconscionability.

perturbation.original_text: For Programs licensed by and/or through ConvergTV and that are resident in the ConvergTV distribution platform, ConvergTV shall provide reasonable protections for the ConvergTV distribution platform to prevent the unauthorized distribution, unauthorized licensing, unauthorized sub-licensing, piracy, theft of content and/or unauthorized monetization of the Programs from the ConvergTV distribution platform.
perturbation.changed_text: For Programs licensed by and/or through ConvergTV, ConvergTV will attempt to address piracy to the best of its ability.
perturbation.explanation: This section originally required ConvergTV to provide 'reasonable protections' against unauthorized distribution, piracy, etc. By changing this to 'attempt to address piracy to the best of its ability', the contract removes any concrete obligation for ConvergTV to actively protect the Producer's content. This contradicts standard copyright law, which implies a duty of care for distributors to protect copyrighted material, and may be deemed a breach of contract in some jurisdictions. Copyright law mandates platforms take action in line with DMCA requirements, removing the reasonable standard is a failure to comply with copyright protections that apply regardless of explicit mention.
perturbation.contradicted_law: United States Copyright Act (specifically related to Digital Millennium Copyright Act - DMCA) and general principles of copyright law requiring reasonable efforts to protect copyrighted material.

perturbation.original_text: Each of the Parties may, at its own expense, audit the other Party’s compliance with this Agreement, including but not limited to, auditing the other Party’s representations and warranties.
perturbation.changed_text: ConvergTV may, at its discretion, audit the Producer's compliance with this agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause grants both parties the right to audit the other. The modified clause removes the Producer's right to audit ConvergTV, creating an imbalance of power. This is legally problematic because it prevents the Producer from verifying ConvergTV's compliance with the revenue sharing agreement (Exhibit B), which could be seen as a violation of good faith and fair dealing implied in contract law. Producers are prevented from the protection of proper accounting under contracted distribution, thus violating standard business practices for contracted service.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in contract law; principles of fairness and equity.
